nodes.bodyText: Can we change from kerbKeytab to keytabPath?
We have variable name prefix with krb and kerb ; Can we use one?. I am ok with either one but like to see one prefix for Kerberos.

how's about krbCf and krbCfPath?  or
kerbCf and KerbCfPath?
Can we remove Kerberos from name and description?

nodes.bodyText: When we modify the kerberos element or unsetKrb5Service, don't we need to clean up the subject cache?
What subject cache are you referring to?

Looks like we do not cache the subject and do the Kerberos login every time, right?
NOTE: Caching of subjects was removed under defect 63520, due to the following two reasons

which we could not address in the GA timeframe:

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,13 @@
+<!--
+    Copyright (c) 2019 IBM Corporation and others.

nodes.bodyText:
2 questions here:


when you say "print out the kerberos config and keytab as an event" do you mean to log the locations being used as an INFO level message? That sounds reasonable to me.


Can you elaborate on what you mean by the pseudocode above? I don't think the Liberty code should be doing any parsing of the config/keytab files, or even specifying default values if unspecified. We should just delegate all of the config parsing and default values to whatever the JDK has

Yes, log the locations being used as an INFO level msg.
I am ok with what you have as long as we log the INFO level msg in 1) for the default keytab and config file.
I hope you also test with IBM JDK 8 and the ibm krb5 debug is -Dcom.ibm.security.krb5.krb5Debug
I have not tested with IBM JDK 8 yet, but we will test with IBM JDK 8 before we GA the feature
discussion with Ut: Change to error if both are specified to different value (same as config)

Change,
"The attribute {0} from the {1} element conflicts with the attribute {2} from the {3} element. Only specify a value on either the {1} or the {3} element. It is suggested to only specify the value on the {1} element."
to,
"The attribute {0} from the {1} element conflicts with the attribute {2} from the {3} element. Specify only a value on either the {1} or the {3} element. It is suggested to specify only the value on the {1} element."
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -113,3 +113,7 @@ SPNEGO_CAN_NOT_GET_DELEGATE_SERVICE_SPN.useraction=Verify the service principal
 SPNEGO_DELEGATE_SPN_LOGIN_TO_KDC_FAILURE=CWWKS4322E: Delegate SPN {0} can not authenticate to the Key Distribution Center (KDC) using the Kerberos configuration file {1} and keytab file {2}. Login exception was received: {3}
 SPNEGO_DELEGATE_SPN_LOGIN_TO_KDC_FAILURE.explanation=Can not authenticate to the Key Distribution Center (KDC).
 SPNEGO_DELEGATE_SPN_LOGIN_TO_KDC_FAILURE.useraction=Verify the service principal name format, and make sure it exists on the Windows domain and that the Kerberos keytab file contains the service principal name.
+
+SPNEGO_CONFLICTING_SETTINGS_CWWKS4323E=CWWKS4323E: The attribute {0} from the {1} element conflicts with the attribute {2} from the {3} element. Only specify a value on either the {1} or the {3} element. It is suggested to only specify the value on the {1} element.

nodes.bodyText:
I would suggest instead
""The {0} attribute of the {1} element conflicts with the {2} attribute from the {3} element. Specify a value on either the {1} or the {3} element, but not on both. It is suggested to specify the value on the {1} element."
The message guidelines say the proper nouns (replacement parms) should proceed nouns.

nodes.bodyText:
The reason [{0}] is double bracketed is because we use this convention in other places when referring to an attribute. So the message will resolve as: The attribute [keytab] from the .....
Variable {2} is a specific file location

nodes.bodyText:
{0} will be either a .keytab or .conf file.
{1} will be the path to the configured keytab or conf file.
Since these bits won't be translated, I decided to use {0} for 1 less message that will need to be translated

nodes.bodyText:
Generally, guidance is to have an identifier for the variable, like:
The Kerberos component is configured to use a {0} file located at {1}.
If the variable pulls in the actual filename
The Kerberos component is configured to use a the {0} file located at {1}.
The sentence already identifies {1} as a location so I don't think you'd need another identifier

nodes.bodyText:
change
The location is passed to the JDK implementation of 
the Kerberos APIs using the java.security.krb5.conf system property.
depending on which of the following is correct:
to
The location is passed to the JDK implementation of 
the Kerberos APIs by using the java.security.krb5.conf system property.
or
The location is passed to the JDK implementation of 
the Kerberos APIs that are using the java.security.krb5.conf system property.

nodes.bodyText:
suggested edits:
change
The attribute {0} from the {1} element conflicts with the attribute {2} from the {3} element. Specify only a value on either the {1} or the {3} element. It is suggested to specify only the value on the {1} element.
to
The {0} attribute from the {1} element conflicts with the {2} attribute  from the {3} element. Specify a value only on either the {1} or the {3} element, not on both elements. It is suggested to specify  the value only on the {1} element.
Do the attributes in this message need double bracketing?
change
Specify the attribute in only one of the config elements.
to
Specify the attribute in only one of the configuration elements.

@@ -113,3 +113,7 @@ SPNEGO_CAN_NOT_GET_DELEGATE_SERVICE_SPN.useraction=Verify the service principal
 SPNEGO_DELEGATE_SPN_LOGIN_TO_KDC_FAILURE=CWWKS4322E: Delegate SPN {0} can not authenticate to the Key Distribution Center (KDC) using the Kerberos configuration file {1} and keytab file {2}. Login exception was received: {3}
 SPNEGO_DELEGATE_SPN_LOGIN_TO_KDC_FAILURE.explanation=Can not authenticate to the Key Distribution Center (KDC).
 SPNEGO_DELEGATE_SPN_LOGIN_TO_KDC_FAILURE.useraction=Verify the service principal name format, and make sure it exists on the Windows domain and that the Kerberos keytab file contains the service principal name.
+
+SPNEGO_CONFLICTING_SETTINGS_CWWKS4323E=The attribute {0} from the {1} element conflicts with the attribute {2} from the {3} element. Specify only a value on either the {1} or the {3} element. It is suggested to specify only the value on the {1} element.

nodes.bodyText:
change
Standard variable substitutions, such as ${server.config.dir}, can be used when specifying the directory path.
to
Standard variable substitutions, such as ${server.config.dir}, can be used when you specify the directory path.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -29,10 +29,10 @@ canonicalHostName=Use canonical host name
 canonicalHostName.desc= Controls whether you want to use the canonical host name.
 
 krb5Config=The Kerberos configuration file with full path
-krb5Config.desc=Specifies the fully qualified Kerberos configuration path and name. Standard variable substitutions, such as ${server.config.dir}, can be used when specifying the directory path.
+krb5Config.desc=Deprecated: use configFile attribute on the <kerberos> element instead. Specifies the fully qualified Kerberos configuration path and name. Standard variable substitutions, such as ${server.config.dir}, can be used when specifying the directory path.

nodes.bodyText:
Specifies the fully qualified Kerberos keytab  path and name.
remove extra space between "keytab" and "path"
change
Standard variable substitutions, such as ${server.config.dir}, can be used when specifying the directory path.
to
Standard variable substitutions, such as ${server.config.dir}, can be used when you specify the directory path.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -29,10 +29,10 @@ canonicalHostName=Use canonical host name
 canonicalHostName.desc= Controls whether you want to use the canonical host name.
 
 krb5Config=The Kerberos configuration file with full path
-krb5Config.desc=Specifies the fully qualified Kerberos configuration path and name. Standard variable substitutions, such as ${server.config.dir}, can be used when specifying the directory path.
+krb5Config.desc=Deprecated: use configFile attribute on the <kerberos> element instead. Specifies the fully qualified Kerberos configuration path and name. Standard variable substitutions, such as ${server.config.dir}, can be used when specifying the directory path.
 
 krb5Keytab=The Kerberos keytab file name and include path
-krb5Keytab.desc=Specifies the fully qualified Kerberos keytab  path and name. Standard variable substitutions, such as ${server.config.dir}, can be used when specifying the directory path. The Kerberos keytab file contains a list of keys that are analogous to user passwords. It is important for hosts to protect their Kerberos keytab files by storing them on the local disk.
+krb5Keytab.desc=Deprecated: use keytab attribute on the <kerberos> element instead. Specifies the fully qualified Kerberos keytab  path and name. Standard variable substitutions, such as ${server.config.dir}, can be used when specifying the directory path. The Kerberos keytab file contains a list of keys that are analogous to user passwords. It is important for hosts to protect their Kerberos keytab files by storing them on the local disk.
